arguments.claim: moneys brought into British India were moneys of the sellers not appellant's as post office was agent of sellers property transferred in Srinagar hence no liability to tax

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then put in this way The remittances had been made on account of price of goods purchased by the appellants in British India. These remittances had been made by telegraphic money orders despatched from Srinagar post offices and by bank drafts sent by post from Srinagar. The remitter, that is the appellant, had no control over the moneys covered by the telegraphic money-orders or the bank drafts, once the instructions for the telegraphic money-orders had been give or the bank drafts issued and, therefore, the moneys covered by them were thereafter no the appellants moneys.
